Authors:
Shihomi Uzuhashi, Haruka Ikeda, Ai Kamekawa, Lorien E.
Radmer, Sakura Kobayashi, Katsutoshi Kuroda, Taichi Funakubo, Kazunori
Ichikawa, Motoaki Tojo
Title:
Presence of two intraspecific phylogenetic groups among
Globisporangium splendens isolates in Japan
Keywords:
geranium, intraspecific, mating compatibility, papaya,
phylogenetic groups, Pythium splendens
Abstract:
Globisporangium splendens, formerly classified as Pythium
splendens, is the most common pathogenic oomycetes on ornamental plants,
but has rarely been characterized in its intraspecific variations of
molecular phylogeny and virulence. In this study, G. splendens isolates
from seven Prefectures in Japan, were characterized on their morphology,
mating compatibility, and molecular phylogeny based on the internal
transcribed spacer region of ribosomal RNA gene, and mitochondrial
cytochrome oxidase 1 and 2 gene regions. They were also examined
virulence on geranium and papaya which known to be host plants of G.
splendens. All G. splendens isolates had similar morphology and optimal
growth temperatures. Mating compatibility test revealed that all G.
splendens isolates from Okinawa and Kagoshima Pref. were antheridial
isolates. While, the all isolates from the other regions were oogonial
isolates. The virulence on geranium and papaya significantly differed
among the isolates. Phylogenetic analyses based on the sequences of
three regions showed that G. splendens isolates were separated into two
phylogenetic groups. Our study indicates that molecular intraspecific
variation of G. splendens is widely distributed in Japan, and it had no
correlation with morphology, mating types and virulence to host
plants.
